natural problem: I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth.
natural solution: There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set" and E :: real
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card marbles = 5"
and h2 : "E = (\<Sum>(a, b) \<in> marbles \<times> marbles - Id. a * b) / ((card marbles) * (card marbles - 1))"
shows  "E = 8.5"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set" and E :: real
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card marbles = 5"
and h2 : "E = (\<Sum>(a, b) \<in> marbles \<times> marbles - Id. a * b) / ((card marbles) * (card marbles - 1))"
shows  "E = 8.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 5 distinct marbles numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Calculate the expected value of the product of two distinct marbles chosen at random. The final answer is 8.5.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes marbles :: "nat set"
and product :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1..5}"
and h1 : "finite marbles"
and h2 : "card marbles = 5"
and h3 : "(\<forall>x y. x \<in> marbles \<and> y \<in> marbles \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> product x y = real (x * y))"
and h4 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>(x, y)\<in>(marbles \<times> marbles) - Id. product x y) / (card (marbles \<times> marbles) - card Id)"
shows  "expected_value = 8.5"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes marbles :: "nat set"
and product :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1..5}"
and h1 : "finite marbles"
and h2 : "card marbles = 5"
and h3 : "(\<forall>x y. x \<in> marbles \<and> y \<in> marbles \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> product x y = real (x * y))"
and h4 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>(x, y)\<in>(marbles \<times> marbles) - Id. product x y) / (card (marbles \<times> marbles) - card Id)"
shows  "expected_value = 8.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 5 marbles numbered from 1 to 5. If you randomly pick two distinct marbles and multiply their numbers, what is the expected value of this product? The final answer is 8.5.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes marbles :: "nat set" and draw :: "nat set" and E :: "real"
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card draw = 2"
and h2 : "draw \<subseteq> marbles"
and h3 : "E = (\<Sum>(x, y)\<in>draw \<times> draw - Id. x * y) / (real (card marbles) * (real (card marbles) - 1))"
shows  "E = 8.5"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes marbles :: "nat set" and draw :: "nat set" and E :: "real"
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card draw = 2"
and h2 : "draw \<subseteq> marbles"
and h3 : "E = (\<Sum>(x, y)\<in>draw \<times> draw - Id. x * y) / (real (card marbles) * (real (card marbles) - 1))"
shows  "E = 8.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a set of marbles numbered from 1 to 5, if you randomly draw 2 marbles without replacement, find the expected value of the product of the numbers on the drawn marbles. The final answer is 8.5.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set"
and f :: "(int \<times> int) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card marbles = 5"
and h2 : "finite marbles"
and h3 : "\<forall>(x, y) \<in> marbles \<times> marbles. x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> f (x, y) = real (x * y)"
shows  "sum f (marbles \<times> marbles) / (int (card (marbles \<times> marbles)) - card marbles) = 8.5"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set"
and f :: "(int \<times> int) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card marbles = 5"
and h2 : "finite marbles"
and h3 : "\<forall>(x, y) \<in> marbles \<times> marbles. x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> f (x, y) = real (x * y)"
shows  "sum f (marbles \<times> marbles) / (int (card (marbles \<times> marbles)) - card marbles) = 8.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are five marbles numbered 1 through 5. Calculate the average product of the numbers of two distinct marbles. The final answer is 8.5.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set" and expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card marbles = 5"
and h2 : "two_marbles_probability marbles = 1 / 10"
and h3 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>(a, b)\<in>marbles\<times>marbles - Id. a * b * two_marbles_probability marbles)"
shows  "expected_value = 8.5"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set" and expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card marbles = 5"
and h2 : "two_marbles_probability marbles = 1 / 10"
and h3 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>(a, b)\<in>marbles\<times>marbles - Id. a * b * two_marbles_probability marbles)"
shows  "expected_value = 8.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: There are 5 marbles numbered from 1 to 5 in a bag. You are to draw two marbles without replacement, and their product is recorded as the score. The probability of drawing any two marbles is 1/10. What is the expected value of the score? The final answer is 8.5.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "\<forall> m1 m2. m1 \<in> marbles \<and> m2 \<in> marbles \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>! p. p = m1 * m2)"
shows  "8.5 = (SUM p : {m1 * m2 | m1 m2. m1 \<in> marbles \<and> m2 \<in> marbles \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2} . p) / card {m1 * m2 | m1 m2. m1 \<in> marbles \<and> m2 \<in> marbles \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2}"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "\<forall> m1 m2. m1 \<in> marbles \<and> m2 \<in> marbles \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>! p. p = m1 * m2)"
shows  "8.5 = (SUM p : {m1 * m2 | m1 m2. m1 \<in> marbles \<and> m2 \<in> marbles \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2} . p) / card {m1 * m2 | m1 m2. m1 \<in> marbles \<and> m2 \<in> marbles \<and> m1 \<noteq> m2}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 5 marbles labeled with integers 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Calculate the average of all distinct pairs' product (i.e., the product of the labels of two different marbles). The final answer is 8.5.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes E :: real
assumes h0 : "E = (\<Sum>(i, j)\<in>{(i, j). i \<in> {1..5} \<and> j \<in> {1..5} \<and> i \<noteq> j}. real (i * j)) / 20"
shows  "E = 8.5"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes E :: real
assumes h0 : "E = (\<Sum>(i, j)\<in>{(i, j). i \<in> {1..5} \<and> j \<in> {1..5} \<and> i \<noteq> j}. real (i * j)) / 20"
shows  "E = 8.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the average value of the products of all distinct pairs of numbers $(i, j)$, where $i$ and $j$ are integers from 1 to 5. The final answer is 8.5.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set"
and E :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card marbles = 5"
and h2 : "finite marbles"
and h3 : "E = (\<lambda>A. sum (\<lambda>(x, y). real x * real y) (setprod marbles A) / (int (card marbles) * (int (card marbles) - 1)))"
shows  "E marbles = 8.5"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes marbles :: "int set"
and E :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "marbles = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}"
and h1 : "card marbles = 5"
and h2 : "finite marbles"
and h3 : "E = (\<lambda>A. sum (\<lambda>(x, y). real x * real y) (setprod marbles A) / (int (card marbles) * (int (card marbles) - 1)))"
shows  "E marbles = 8.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: There is a set of marbles with numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Calculate the expected value of the product of two different marbles selected at random. The final answer is 8.5.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes expected_value :: real and marbles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "finite {1,2,3,4,5}"
and h1 : "card {1,2,3,4,5} = 5"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1,2,3,4,5}. marbles i = i"
and h3 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>(i, j) \<in> {(i, j) | i j. i \<in> {1,2,3,4,5} \<and> j \<in> {1,2,3,4,5} \<and> i \<noteq> j}. marbles i * marbles j) / real (card {(i, j) | i j. i \<in> {1,2,3,4,5} \<and> j \<in> {1,2,3,4,5} \<and> i \<noteq> j})"
shows  "expected_value = 8.5"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 marbles numbered 1 through 5 in a bag.  Suppose I take out two different marbles at random.  What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the marbles?  Answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth. The final Answer is 8.5
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{5}{2} = 10$ different pairs of marbles that can be drawn, and the expected value of the product is the average of the products of each pair. This is  \begin{align} \frac{1}{10}[(1\times 2)&+(1\times 3)+(1\times 4)+(1\times 5)+{}\\
 &(2\times 3)+(2\times 4)+(2\times 5)+(3\times 4)+(3\times 5)+(4\times 5)]\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad=\frac{85}{10} = \boxed{8.5}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes expected_value :: real and marbles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "finite {1,2,3,4,5}"
and h1 : "card {1,2,3,4,5} = 5"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {1,2,3,4,5}. marbles i = i"
and h3 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>(i, j) \<in> {(i, j) | i j. i \<in> {1,2,3,4,5} \<and> j \<in> {1,2,3,4,5} \<and> i \<noteq> j}. marbles i * marbles j) / real (card {(i, j) | i j. i \<in> {1,2,3,4,5} \<and> j \<in> {1,2,3,4,5} \<and> i \<noteq> j})"
shows  "expected_value = 8.5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are 5 marbles, each labeled with a distinct number from 1 to 5. Two marbles are drawn at random without replacement. What is the expected value of the product of the numbers on the two marbles? The final answer is 8.5.
